newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: Malaysia corn importers hold prices as stocks rise.
newsitem.headline: Malaysia corn importers hold prices as stocks rise.

text.p: Malaysian corn importers were holding on to maize prices on Tuesday, despite local warehouses filled to the rafters with the staple, trader said.
Warehouses in the country had a stockpile of between 150,000 and 170,000 tonnes of corn this week will little room left for new arrivals, traders said.
"This is always a problem with the Malaysian market...you either have too much or little of anything," said a senior trader at a grains house in Singapore.
He said importers were fighting to keep prices steady. "They're holding on bravely, although they know for certain they must come down if there's no demand."
The price of bulk corn, ex-factories/godowns in Malaysia's central region, was at 380 to 385 ringgit per tonne C&F for the second straight week.
One trader said it could take until mid-July or even early August to clear the existing stocks as well as new arrivals projected over the next four weeks.
"For the moment, we have about 30,000 to 50,000 tonnes (of maize) arriving a week," he said. "Once we have a clear idea on when the intake stops, then we'll know when prices could firm again."
Traders said other grains were "practically dead" on activity.
"A" grade wheat in bags was unchanged at 730 ringgit a tonne. "B" grade wheat was also steady at 430 ringgit.
Soymeal was maintained at 880 ringgit a tonne for the local material and 870 ringgit for imported.
